Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Situation2: They develop a comprehensive design for a hospital wing, ensuring critical areas like operating rooms and emergency routes function seamlessly.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, tracing the lines of the new hospital wing. Every detail mattered—emergency routes, the flow between operating rooms, the placement of every door and window. My phone buzzed, and I saw my mother’s message: “Don’t forget, you’re leading the family ceremony this weekend. It means so much to your grandparents.” My heart tightened. I knew how important it was to them, to all of us, to keep our traditions alive. They expected me to guide the rituals, to honor our ancestors, to be present in every sense. But the hospital project deadline loomed, and my team depended on me to finalize the plans. Patients’ lives could hinge on my decisions. I felt pulled in two directions—one by the weight of family legacy, the other by the responsibility to create a space that could save lives. The expectations pressed in from both sides, and I sat there, torn, unable to see how I could possibly meet them all.
